subject: DBRS Confirms Italy at BBB (high), Stable Trend
US MARKET WRAP: USD hit despite core CPI rise, stocks climb to fresh record highs
content:
US MARKET WRAP: USD hit despite core CPI rise, stocks climb to fresh record highs

FEDSPEAK: Non-voters Kashkari and Harker do not reveal any new information

Fed’s Harker (non-voter) was again on the wires on Friday, and said little new information of note. However, he did repeat his view that the Fed should lift rates two times in 2018 (the Fed’s dots look for three hikes).  

Fed’s Kashkari (non-voter) spoke once again on Friday, focusing on inflation data; the Minneapolis Fed President is gopeful that inflation is moving to target, but wants to see more evidence.

US CPI: Core inflation rises more than expected

US CPI YY, NSA (Dec) 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.2%)
US CPI MM, SA (Dec) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%)
US Core CPI YY, NSA (Dec) 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)
US Core CPI MM, SA (Dec) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)
US Real Weekly Earnings MM (Dec) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%)

Traders focused on the core CPI measure, which rose to 1.8% in December, the latest monthly increase in almost a year.

EQUITIES: SPX +0.66% at 2786, DJI +0.88% at 25800, NDX +0.75% at 6758
Top performers: Consumer cyclicals +1.0%, Energy +0.8%, Industrials +0.7%
Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.4%, Consumer non-cyclicals +0.1%, Materials +0.1%

The equities rally continues, with major US bourses printing fresh record highs at the end of the week, as Q4 earnings season gets underway.

Banks began reporting their numbers, with JPMorgan reporting a top and bottom-line beat; Wells Fargo, however, could only beat on the Adj EPS front, with revenues falling slightly short of expectations. The former’s trading revenues were glum, as expected, with fixed income trading off by over 30%, while equities trading revenues were flat.

Consumer discretionary led the gains after retail sales increased. Energy was also higher, tracking crude prices. On the other end of the scale, utilities were the laggard, once again.

TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 6 ticks lower at 122-30

Although Treasury yields were slightly higher on the day (with the exception of 30s, which were unchanged), major curves flattened; most notably, the 2s30s curve, by c.3.6bps.

2s yields rose by around 3bps on the day following a decent core CPI data print, which has nudged the probability of three Fed hikes in 2018 slightly higher.

Corporate supply has been healthy this week, with high-grade raising $32bln, according to Reuters. Next week, high grade issuers are forecast to raise between $25 and $30bln.

FOREX: USD lower despite healthy core CPI

The Greenback found strength after core CPI data rose more than analysts had expected. However, the buck found is difficult to cling onto gains, and continued to ease gradually in wake of the release, and as yields gave back some of their gains.

The EUR was supported by positive news from Germany, where parties have reached an ‘accord’ to form a government, possibly by the end of February, driving the currency to the highest levels since 2014, now flirting with 1.22.

Later in the day, the weaker dollar was helping the single EUR saw some small downticks in late European trade, after ECB member Jens Weidmann suggested that the prospects of an imminent rate hike from the ECB were small.

The yen was pushed to beneath 111.0 in wake of the US CPI data, though is consolidating around the figure as we head into the weekend. The Swissy also gained, breaching the 0.97 figure against the USD; as did gold, rising towards the $1340 mark.

Sterling took advantage of USD weakness, pushing above 1.37. There were reports in the afternoon suggesting that Spain and the Netherlands were amenable to a soft-Brexit, providing some impetus for Sterling bulls.

CAD continues to be subject to NAFTA headline risk, though worries have eased slightly on a US-led deadline extension, remaining beneath 1.25 heading into the weekend.

CRUDE: WTI futures settle 50 cents higher at USD 64.30 per barrel; Brent futures settle 61 cents higher at USD 69.87 per barrel

Crude prices rose on Friday, though Brent couldn’t settle above $70 per barrel. Comments from the Russian energy minister supported the crude complex, after he said that markets were not balanced yet. The comments were said to undermined the argument that OPEC/Non-OPEC were edging towards unwinding their deal to curb output.

Baker Hughes reported that active oil rigs rose by 10 in the week to 752, the largest weekly increase since June.

Finally, oil specs raised net longs by around 46k to 501k in the week.

subject: Boston Scientific (BSX) announces positive results from whisper spinal cord stimulation study
FX Weekly Wrap: frantic Friday to end whippy week
content:
USD

The Dollar Index is ending a turbulent week under pressure again and below 91.500 with only brief and mild relief coming from US CPI (core inflation firmer than expected) and Retail Sales data (broadly in line, but back month revised up). The DXY hit a circa 91.2500 low and the 2017 low at 91.011 is the next/nearest downside level unless the Greenback can stage a more meaningful and sustained recovery, which looks unlikely given ongoing strength elsewhere.

EUR

Only eclipsed by the Gbp as Friday’s G10 top performer, but still the clear winner on the week as hawkish ECB minutes combined with a breakthrough in Germany’s grand coalition Government talks propelled the single currency through several key upside markers. Last year’s 1.2092 peak vs the Usd was surpassed with ease along with 1.2100 as buying interest at and just above the figure pushed the headline pair up to a high around 1.2150. 1.2167-69 next on the radar for bulls. Eur/Jpy took out offers and resistance from 134.85-135.00 on the way to a 135.35 peak, but Eur/Gbp was unable to build on gains above 0.8900 and retreated below on some positive Brexit developments.

GBP

Sterling also improved on its 2017 best vs the Usd (1.3657) as Cable almost rallied to 1.3700 on reports that Spain and the Netherlands favour a soft Brexit. The Pound gained across the board on this positive news, reclaiming 152.00+ status vs the Jpy from lows not far from 150.50 earlier.

CHF/CAD

Both firmer vs the Greenback, with Usd/Chf close to 0.9700 and key tech support at 0.9699, while the Loonie tested 1.2500 again on hopes that an extension to NAFTA negotiations may help resolve differences, but could not get close to levels seen this time last week (1.2355) on the bumper jump in Canadian jobs (other data since less upbeat, like building permits on Wednesday).

 JPY

Volatile vs the Usd all week, but a net gainer having cleared bids around 111.00 and on track to close below 111.84 (30 WMA), if not 111.53 (Fib), which would keep the pair in a downtrend and eyeing major chart support around 110.84.

AUD/NZD

The antipopdeans have both lost momentum vs the US counterpart towards the end of the week, with Aud/Usd slipping back from just over 0.7900 on weaker than forecast Chinese imports and the Kiwi retreating from 0.7275 towards 0.7220 having failed to challenge the next round number. However, Aud remains underpinned ahead of the 0.7855 200DMA.

Fixed Income latest: more volatile trade
content: The US data has sparked more downside in bonds, with US Treasuries revisiting levels seen on the original Chinese headlines about slowing or halting purchases of US debt, ie lows in futures and highs in yields, with 2 year cash actually a bit firmer and just over 2% on firmer March Fed rate hike expectations. Bunds and Gilts fell to 160.11 and 123.26 respectively (-20 and -59 ticks), with the latter also digesting reports that Spain and the Netherlands are both looking for a soft Brexit. The latter has hit the Short Sterling strip hard as BoE tightening could come sooner on a transition and divorce agreement that limits any economic fall-out, and more option plays look for a May hike via a diagonal calendar put spread or roll. Core 10 year benchmarks are off extremes presently, but bears are back in control.

subject: Daily US Equity Opening News - Earnings From Blackrock (BLK), JP Morgan (JPM) & Wells Fargo (WFC)
content:
12th January 2018

EARNINGS

JP Morgan (JPM) – Q4 (USD) EPS 1.76 vs Exp. 1.69, Revenue 25.5bln vs. Exp. 25.2bln. Fixed income revenues declined by 34% in the quarter, while equity revenues were flat. (Newswires)

Wells Fargo (WFC) – Q4 (USD) Adj. 1.16 vs Exp. 1.06, Revenue 22.1bln vs Exp. 22.4bln. It also reports a net interest margin in Q4 2017 was 12.3bln, down 136mln compared with Q3 2017.  Residential mortgage originations in Q4 totalled 53bln vs 59bln in Q3. The bank also remains committed to its expense reductions target of 2bln. (Newswires)

Blackrock (BLK) – Q4 (USD) Adj. EPS 6.24 vs Exp. 6.02, Revenue 3.47bln vs Exp. 3.32bln. It also raises its quarterly dividend by 15% to 2.88/shr. (Newswires) 

Infosys (INFY) – Q3 (USD) EPS 0.35, vs Exp. 0.26, Revenue 2.755bln vs Exp. 2.75bln. (Newswires)

PNC Financial (PNC) – Q4 (USD) Adj. EPS 2.29, vs Exp. 2.20, Revenue 4.26bln vs Exp. 4.20bln. (Newswires)

 

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant has warned Chinese users who tried to avoid a cybersecurity law by creating overseas ID’s, that their personal data could be lost. (Newswires)

Intel (INTC) – The chipmaker has received reports from customers that they have experienced higher system reboots after applying firmware updates. (Newswires)

Wal-Mart (WMT) – The retail giant confirms the closure of 63 Sam’s Club stores. (Newswires)

 

S&P 500

Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) – The chipmaker announced its chips are affected by Spectre security flaw, this comes after it recently said the risk for them being susceptible was near zero. (CNBC)

Delta Air Lines (DAL) – As the Chinese aviation authority is cracking down on foreign companies calling Taiwan and Tibet countries, Delta has issued an apology as requested. (Newswires)

Ford (F) – The automaker announced it is going to recall nearly 3000 Ranger vehicles fitted with Takata airbag inflators. (Newswires)

GameStop (GME) – The co. reports holiday Same Store Sales up 11.8%. Further, it now forecasts FY17 Adj. EPS view in the middle of its (USD) 3.10 – 3.40 range, vs Exp. 3.32. (Newswires)

General Motors (GM) – The automaker is looking for consent from the US government for its first fully autonomous car to be introduced into its commercial ride sharing fleet in 2019, the car will have accommodative features for those who have impaired vision and hearing. (Newswires)

Johnson Controls (JCI) – The electronic equipment director announced a purchase of 12,000 ordinary shares at USD 36.4097 (Newswires)

Microsoft (MSFT) – Wells Fargo has raised the co. price target to (USD) 100 from 90. (Newswires)

Noble Energy (NE) – The co. CEO, David Williams announced his retirement, with Julie Robertson to succeed. (Newswires)

Northern Trust (NTRS) – The asset management co. is to acquire technology resources from Citadel; financial terms not disclosed. (Newswires)

Pitney Bowes (PBI) – The co. says, ‘we do not comment on rumours or speculation’ regarding the received takeover interest from Blackstone (BX) and Carlyle Group (CG). (Newswires)

Time Warner (TWX) – The co.’s HBO signs Ronan Farrow to create a new investigative series. (NYT)

 

NASDAQ 100

Alphabet (GOOG) – Morgan Stanley raises price target to (USD) 1210 from 1150. (Newswires)

Baidu (BIDU) – China has issued a warning to tech companies over privacy policies. (CNBC)

Facebook (FB) – The social media giant’s CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, posted he is instructing teams to change the way Facebook is built, and he stated that users of the platform will see less public business, brands and media content with changes to take place this month. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – Qualcomm announced it is extending its cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of NXP Semiconductors to 5pm ET on February 9th. (Newswires)

 

OTHER NEWS

Canadian Solar (CSIQ) – The co. has cut its Q4 revenue forecast to 1.04bln – 1.08bln from 1.77bln – 1.81bln vs. Exp. 1.7bln. It also cuts its FY17 revenue forecast to 3.33bln – 3.37bln from 4.05bln - 4.09bln, vs Exp. 3.96bln. (Newswires)

Cars.com (CARS) – Starboard value has cut its stake in the co. to 7% from 9%. (Newswires)

Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) – The automaker is to invest over USD 1bln in a Michigan plant, which will add 2500 new jobs. Further reports suggest that NAFTA uncertainty plays a role in this move. (Newswires / Free Press)

Finisar (FNSR) – The co. CEO and chairman, Jerry Rawls announced his retirement with Michael Hurston to succeed, who recently served as Senior VP at Broadcom (AVGO). (Newswires)

Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) – The Federal Communications Commission halted the co.’s plan to acquire Tribune Media Company as the agency requires to fully review the proposal of divestitures. (Newswires)

Toll Brothers (TOL) – Its newly purchased lots are valued at USD 1bln. (Newswires)

SS&C (SSNC) – Needham have raised the co. price target to (USD) 60 from 44. (Newswires)

Twitter (TWTR) - Price target raised to (USD) 30 from 25 at BTIG. (Newswires)

subject: PREVIEW: US CPI (Dec) to be released at 13:30 GMT/08:30 ET/07:30 CT
content:
EXPECTATIONS:
- CPI YY is seen unchanged at 2.2%
- CPI MM is seen at 0.2% vs previous 0.4%
- Core CPI YY is seen at 1.8% vs. previous 1.7%
- Core CPI MM seen at 0.2% vs previous 0.1%

PREVIEW:

Headline US consumer price rises are expected to moderate in MM terms, while the core metrics are expected tick up.

Energy prices remained subdued in December, as gasoline prices fell 3%, and RBC estimates that this will translate into an adjusted decline of 1% for the energy component.

On the core front RBC says that “ex-energy, services has substantial momentum as it continues to unwind the early 2017 idiosyncratic impacts (namely the downdraft in wireless plan prices) and we fully expect core prices to take out 2% once again around the middle of 2018.”

BMO adopts a similar view, stating that “despite a setback in November owing predominately to aggressive price discounting of apparel, the shorter-term core CPI inflation trends are still turning up shedding the negative idiosyncratic factors from earlier in the year.”

Recent Fedspeak has been mixed regarding the number of hikes that Committee members are looking for in 2018, with dovishness being inspired by a perceived weakness in inflation.   

Predictably, Mester (voter) stuck to her hawkish leanings on Friday, when she stated that she would be happy with 3 or 4 hikes in 2018 following the strong December jobs report and given that the US economy is operating at its “full-employment level.” She believes that the economic expansion is firmly in place and sees inflation rising gradually to 2% in the next couple of years.

Williams (voter) also stuck to script on Saturday, suggesting that the Fed should look to hike 3 times in 2018 given the strong economic backdrop and the expected boost resulting from tax reform. On Monday he added that inflation targeting is resulting in average inflation coming in lower than target, and suggested that price level targeting could solve that particular issue.

Elsewhere, Bostic (voter) struck a dovish tone, stating that he sees no need for 3 hikes in 2018 given the current weak inflation situation, although he did stress that 3 hikes could occur if the data improves, but he was wary of issues that could be created by yield curve inversion.

Last week Harker (non-voter) surprised the markets as he stated that he deems two hikes in 2018 as appropriate. He also noted that if soft inflation continues it may make the 2% inflation target harder to reach. 

Rosengren (non-voter) suggested that the FOMC could introduce an inflation target range of 1.5%-3.0%, while Kashkari (non-voter) stuck to his dovish playbook, reiterating that at present, too low inflation was more of an issue than too high inflation.

On the whole the recent rhetoric ratifies December’s FOMC meeting minutes, where a few policymakers noted that December’s economic projections would result in too many rate hikes in 2018, while a few others believed more hikes would be required (relative to a median of 3 hikes).

subject: Russia's Lukoil chief says that if the oil price remains at USD 70/bbl we should start exiting OPEC+ deal smoothly
PNC Financial Services (PNC) Q4 2017 Earnings (USD): Adj EPS 2.29 (Exp. 2.20), Revenue 4.26bln (Exp. 4.2bln)
JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) Q4 2017 Earnings (USD): Adj EPS 1.76 (Exp. 1.69), Revenue 25.5bln (Exp. 25.2bln)
content:
- Fixed Income revenues declined by 34%

- Equity revenues flat

subject: UAE Energy minister states that we cannot talk about oil price before the market is balanced; he expects the OPEC deal to last till the end of 2018 as the member states are prepared to stay committed to the deal
BlackRock Inc (BLK) Q4 2017 Earnings (USD): adj. EPS USD 6.24 (Exp. USD 6.02), Revenue USD 3.47bln (Exp. USD 3.3bln)
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: EUR takes out 2017 highs and the 1.2100 level after German coalition talks make a breakthrough
content:
• EUR takes out 2017 highs and the 1.2100 level after German coalition talks make a breakthrough
  • European equities trade with little in the way of firm direction as EUR gains cap upside for the DAX
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, retail sales and earnings from Wells Fargo, JP Morgan and Blackrock

ASIA

Asia equity markets are mostly positive following record highs across all major US indices on optimism heading into earnings season and where energy outperformed with oil at 3yr highs. ASX 200 (Unch) was kept positive throughout the day by commodity-related stocks, but still closed flat due to losses in the largest weighted financials sector. In Japan, index-heavyweight Fast Retailing outperformed and hit its highest in over 2 years after strong quarterly results, although the Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) failed to benefit with the broader market negative on JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and was positive following better than expected Chinese Trade Surplus and Exports, as well as a more convincing liquidity effort by the PBoC. However, the Shanghai Comp (+0.1%) was less decisive as participants also digested disappointing Import numbers and the fact that open market operations still resulted to a net weekly drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid the dampened risk tone in Japan and amid slightly firmer demand in the 40yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 140bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 130bln via 14-day reverse repos. This resulted to a daily net injection of CNY 180bln, but also a weekly net drain of CNY 60bln vs. last week's CNY 510bln net drain. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4932 (Prev. 6.5147)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Dec) 362.0B vs. Exp. 235.2B (Prev. 263.6B). (Newswires)

Chinese Exports (CNY)(Dec) Y/Y 7.4% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 10.3%)

Chinese Imports (CNY)(Dec) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 11.8% (Prev. 15.6%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 54.69B vs. Exp. 37.00B (Prev. 40.21B). (Newswires)

Chinese Exports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 10.9% vs. Exp. 10.8% (Prev. 12.3%)

Chinese Imports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 4.5% vs. Exp. 15.1% (Prev. 17.7%)

China Customs said China trade outlook is upbeat for this year, but added it will be difficult for Chinese trade to maintain double-digit growth. (Newswires)

Chinese trust companies reportedly placed caps on leveraged funds used for equities. (China Securities Journal)

EU/UK/US

Fed's Dudley (voter) said there is a 'strong case' for gradual hikes and that he is worried growth overheating is a risk, while he added the Fed may have to press harder on the breaks at some point. Dudley also said three Fed hikes in 2018 is not an unreasonable starting point and sees inflation rising to target in the medium term and unemployment falling under 4% this year. (Newswires)

German coalition negotiators have achieved a breakthrough according to DPA. Further to this, a German coalition paper shows that parties are committed to strengthening Euro-Zone in close partnership with France. Finally, the CSU expects a government to be formed by Easter. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

South Korea and US are in discussions to develop ties with North Korea, according to Yonhap citing an envoy. (Yonhap)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirms US plans to reimpose sanctions on Iran, while a separate report states the White House plans to announce decision on Friday. (Newswires)

North Korea's propaganda outlet called for the total suspension of joint military drills between South Korea and the United States on Friday, according to Yonhap. (Yonhap)


EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 flat, DAX +0.1%) have been trading with little in the way of firm direction with any potential gains in the DAX (following German coalition talks) capped by EUR strength. In terms of sector specifics, energy names are seen lower, in-fitting with the moves seen in WTI and Brent while consumer discretionary names are outperforming with Fiat (+2.7%) top of the FSTE MIB after unveiling plans to invest further in their Michigan plant and provide bonuses to US workers following US tax legislation. Other individual movers include Vivendi (-1.3%) seen lower after warning on guidance, whilst GKN (+24.7%) after rejecting Melrose’s latest takeover offer; nonetheless, sources suggest that Melrose will continue their pursuit of the Co.

FX

In FX markets, EUR has been extending gains in wake of hawkish December ECB minutes, with added impetus coming from news of a breakthrough in Germany to form a grand coalition Government. EUR/USD showed little resistance this time at last year’s 1.2092 peak or the psychological 1.2100 level with layered macro bids propelling the pair to a circa 1.2135 high (best since December 2014). Tech studies show a bullish target 1.2169, but ultimately the charts signal 1.2350 and 1.2430 (200 MMA) as the next major objectives. On the flip-side, big 2.5bln option expiries at 1.2100 may exert a gravitational pull, but with the USD on the back foot perhaps not (DXY down near 91.30). Indeed, the Dollar is weaker across the board, with Cable tripping stops above 1.3600, USD/JPY eyeing bids at 111.00 and stops below, USD/CAD and USD/CHF both close to big figures or round numbers at 1.2500 and 0.9700 respectively. Antipodeans lagging a bit, but still bid vs the Greenback and only just off overnight peaks (AUD/USD and NZD/USD just below 0.7900 and 0.7275 respectively, with weaker Chinese imports within the latest trade balance perhaps dampening sentiment somewhat).


FIXED INCOME

The relative calm did not last long, for core EU debt at least, as Gilts succumbed to selling pressure and reversed to a fresh Liffe low at 123.69 (-16 ticks vs +9 ticks at best), while Bunds extended to the upside to register a new Eurex peak at 160.62 (+31 ticks vs -14 ticks at worst). FX markets and even faster/frantic trade were the catalyst or driver for moves in bonds with the 10 year German benchmark and even moreso periphery paper the beneficiaries of EUR strength and upbeat tone/fiscal pledges from the new German coalition Government. Off peaks and troughs now as price action abates somewhat, while USTs remain largely side-lined awaiting today’s key data

COMMODITIES

In the energy complex, both WTI and Brent crude futures are seen lower despite the softer USD as Brent makes a pullback from the USD 70.00 level, leading some to question how much further scope there is for the ongoing rally in prices. Energy specific newsflow remains light, however, markets will be on the watch for any announcements today from the White House regarding sanction on Iran. In metals markets, both spot gold and silver have benefitted from the softer USD. Elsewhere, steel futures saw their largest daily decline in a month after three consecutive days of gains as demand faltered overnight. Finally, the latest Chinese trade data saw a 4.3% decline in copper imports for the month of December.

US Commerce Secretary Ross says results of investigation into national security impact from steel imports have been submitted to President Trump who has 90 days to decide on any potential action. (Newswires)

subject: German coalition update; a government should be formed by Easter according to the head of the CSU
Nigeria crude output slipped to 1.68mln bpd in December according to the oil ministry
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: EUR/USD takes out 2017 highs and the 1.2100 handle as German coalition talks make a breakthrough

subject: BofA Merrill Lynch Global Research: Flow Show highlights - New Year kicks off with large equity inflows
content:
Maximum bullish: new year kicks off with blockbuster $24.4bn inflows into equities, big $13.1bn inflows into corporate & EM bonds…the bull capitulation begins.

Barbell boom: 2nd largest week ever of inflows into EM debt, big inflows to IG & HY bonds, 2nd largest inflows into tech...investors double down on bull market leadership; largest 6-week inflows to energy funds...investors chasing laggards too

subject: Fixed Income: divergence in fast markets
content: The relative calm did not last long, for core EU debt at least, as Gilts succumbed to selling pressure and reversed to a fresh Liffe low at 123.69 (-16 ticks vs +9 ticks at best), while Bunds extended to the upside to register a new Eurex peak at 160.62 (+31 ticks vs -14 ticks at worst). FX markets and even faster/frantic trade were the catalyst or driver for moves in bonds with the 10 year German benchmark and even moreso periphery paper the beneficiaries of Eur strength and upbeat tone/fiscal pledges from the new German coalition Government. subject: German SPD Leader Schulz says has unanimously agreed to give party leadership a mandate to negotiate a coalition government

subject: Melrose (MRO LN) stated they will be persistent in putting a bid out for GKN (GKN LN); according to sources
analysis_details: GKN has already rejected a proposal from Melrose

subject: FX Morning Colour: Eur off to Friday flyer, beating 2017 peaks vs Usd
content:
EUR

Extending gains in wake of hawkish December ECB minutes, with added impetus coming from news of a breakthrough in Germany to form a grand coalition Government. Eur/Usd showed little resistance this time at last year’s 1.2092 peak or the psychological 1.2100 level with layered macro bids propelling the pair to a circa 1.2130 high (best since December 2014). Tech studies show a bullish target 1.2169, but ultimately the charts signal 1.2350 and 1.2430 (200 MMA) as the next major objectives. On the flip-side, big 2.5 bn option expiries at 1.2100 may exert a gravitational pull, but with the Usd on the back foot perhaps not (DXY down near 91.500). Indeed, the Dollar is weaker across the board, with Cable looking at stops above 1.3600, Usd/JPY eyeing bids at 111.00 and stops below, Usd/CAD and Usd/CHF both close to big figures or round numbers at 1.2500 and 0.9700 respectively. Antipodeans lagging a bit, but still bid vs the Greenback and only just off overnight peaks (AUD/Usd and NZD/Usd just below 0.7900 and 0.7275 respectively, with weaker Chinese imports within the latest trade balance perhaps dampening sentiment somewhat).

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE HAS NOW FINISHED, PLEASE REVERT BACK TO YOUR ORIGINAL CHANNEL FOR COVERAGE ON THE UK & EUROPEAN SESSION
Riksbank Dep Gov Skingsley said changing policy too soon would be risky.
content: Riksbanks Dep Gov Skingsley says that in his view, the bank should get out of negative environment and into positive levels so they can begin to wind down asset portfolio
analysis_details: - Note, this in-fitting with the most recent minutes release.

subject: EUR moves to a 3yr high as German leaders make breakthrough in coalition talks, subsequently this took EUR past 1.21, while bids just ahead of the figure saw a move to 1.2115 (3yr high)
content: - Alongside this, large option expiries worth around EUR 2.53bln at 1.21 strike has also contributed to the move towards the figure. In terms of levels to look out for the upside, which may provide a bout of resistance is 1.2150, while 1.2169 represents the 50% fib retrace of the fall from the 2014 high (1.3844) to the 2017 low (1.0387)

subject: Further follow-up for German coalition talks; German coalition paper shows that parties are committed to strengthening Euro-Zone in close partnership with France
UK DEBT AND STIRs: firmer for choice in early trade
content: Gilts are garnering some support from another bout of consolidation in Bunds (recently up to 160.51, +20 ticks vs -14 ticks at the low) to trade up at 123.94 (+9 ticks) after an opening wobble and soft start (123.81). However, the rebound from yesterday’s lows looks fragile with US Treasuries still below par and in bear-steepening mode despite a strong long bond auction to end this week’s refunding. Short Sterling futures are flat to a tick ahead, but again lacking clear direction given no domestic data on Friday’s schedule and no fresh Brexit news. Hence, external impulses will continue to dictate and key releases in the pm may be the main drivers (CPI and retail sales) along with any further ECB minutes fall-out.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 154mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 703.4bln; excess liquidity stands at EUR 1.87trl
European equity movers: GKN (GKN LN) +18%, Fiat (FCA IM) +3.5%, Kering (KER FP) +1.3%, Puma (PUM GY) -13%, CHR Hansen (CHR DC) -6%, Vivendi (VIV FP) -4.3%
China Dec aggregate financing (CNY); 1.140tln vs. Exp. 1.500tln
China Dec new Yuan Loans (CNY); 584.4bln vs Exp. 1.00tln
Option expiries of note for today's 10.00am NY cut (1500GMT)
Chinese Dec M2 Money supply y/y 8.2% vs Exp.9.2%
Bunds: bears pounce on opening/early uptick
content: Little respite for German debt futures at the start of the final trading session of the week, with the 10 year bond attempting to claw back some losses initially, but only advancing to 160.44 (after a 160.42 first print) from yesterday’s 160.31 close before sellers regained the upper hand to drive the benchmark down to 160.20. Thursday’s ECB minutes are still reverberating and steepening the curve, as markets recalibrate near term policy expectations in anticipation of revised more hawkish guidance sooner rather than later this year. News that Germany’s main parties have made a breakthrough in coalition talks just sparked another knee-jerk sell-off to 160.17, while the benchmark yield is consolidating gains above 0.50%. Some short covering in futures in wake of in line French inflation data, but a sell into upticks strategy favoured unless the fundamental and technical outlook changes.

subject: French CPI MM (Dec) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)
content: French CPI YY (Dec) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%)

subject: German coalition negotiators have achieved a breakthrough according to DPA
analysis_details: - This comes in the wake of overnight negotiations between the CDU/CSU alliance and the SPD with the breakthrough set to potentially pave the way for Merkel to form a government.

subject: Additional European Equity Stories post the release of the Daily European Equity Opening News...
content:
CHR Hansen (CHR DC) - Q1 revenue EUR 254.5mln vs. Exp. EUR 259mln, Ebit Ex-Items EUR 64.7mln vs. Exp. EUR 68.4mln, affirms outlook. (Newswires)

Electrolux (ELUXB SS) – Co. has proposed Staffan Bohman as their new Chairman. (Newswires)

Gemalto (GTO NA) – Co. expect their merger with Thales (HO FP) to close in H2 2018. (Newswires)

Bovis Homes (BVS LN) - Co. reports total completions at 3645 vs. Prev. 2977, board recommends final dividend of GBP 0.325 vs. Prev. GBP 0.30. Co. says they are on track for significant profit growth in 2018. (Newswires)

Fiat (FCA IM) - Co. are to invest over USD 1bln in their Michigan plant whilst offering USD 2,000 bonuses to US employees. (Newswires)

Novartis (NOVN SW) - Co. have lifted the prices of Cosentyx and Gilenya by 6.5% and 6.0% respectively. (Newswires)

Infineon (IFX GY) - Co. chairman is to step down. (Newswires)

subject: North Korea's propaganda outlet called for the total suspension of joint military drills between South Korea and the United States on Friday, according to Yonhap
DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Vivendi (VIV FP) lowered its revenue and core earnings forecast for 2017. Co. said EBITA would rise between 20% and 25%
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

12th January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were somewhat mixed as the region failed to take full impetus from the record highs across all major US indices on optimism heading into earnings season and where energy outperformed with oil at 3yr highs. ASX 200 (Unch) was kept positive throughout the day by commodity-related stocks, but still closed flat due to losses in the largest weighted financials sector. In Japan, index-heavyweight Fast Retailing outperformed and hit its highest in over 2 years after strong quarterly results, although the Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) failed to benefit with the broader market negative on JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and was positive following better than expected Chinese Trade Surplus and Exports, as well as a more convincing liquidity effort by the PBoC. However, the Shanghai Comp (-0.1%) was less decisive as participants also digested disappointing Import numbers and the fact that open market operations still resulted to a net weekly drain.

FTSE

GSK (GSK LN) – The Telegraph reports that the company could look to take advantage of the recent decline in Vectura’s (VEC LN) share price by making a bid for the Co. (Telegraph) as a guide, Vectura have a market cap. For GBP 772mln.

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. are preparing a bid for Eneca, according to sources. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Carillion (CLLN LN) – Co. is asking creditors to consider a debt extension or a roll-over in financing talks. (Newswires)

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

ROTORK (ROR LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

LADBROKES CORAL (LCL LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The co. says that its Q4 trading revenues were the weakest in 25 years, but the co. stressed that bonuses will be competitive. (Handelsblatt)

BMW (BMW GY), Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - Plans were announced for walkouts at BMW and Volkswagen’s Audi in an attempt to put more pressure on employers in talks over higher wages and shorter hours. While Volkswagen has offered a 2% pay raise for around 120,000 workers in Germany. (Newswires)

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

SAP (SAP GY) RAISED TO EQUAL-WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

VOLKSWAGEN (VOW3 GY) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT MACQUARIE

TUI (TUI GY) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN

CAC

Kering (KER FP) – Co is evaluating options for Puma (PUM GY), options said to include a spin-out to shareholders. (Newswires)

Saint-Gobain (SGO FP) – The co. is to extend its partnership with Alghanim industries to Kuwait, as of 11 January 2018, they have become joint-venture partners in KimmCo. (Newswires)

Carrefour (CA FP) – Co. has agreed to acquire a 17% stake in online fashion retailer Showroomprive.com for EUR 79mln from furniture Co. Conforama. (Newswires)

Societe General (GLE FP) – Co. will book a charge of USD 450mln in Q4 due to a hit from US tax reform. (Newswires)

Danone (BN FP) – Times of India reported Co. is exiting its dairy business in India. (Times of India)

Safran (SAF FP) –Co. has struck a USD 9.1bln agreement as part of a joint venture with General Electric (GE) following French President Macron’s visit to China. (Newswires)

Vivendi (VIV FP) – Co. lowered its revenue and core earnings forecast for 2017. Co. said EBITA would rise between 20% and 25%. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER RECCOMENDATIONS

EDF (EDF FP) UPGRADED TO HOLD FROM SELL AT BERENBERG

DASSAULT SYSTEMS (DSY FP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT EXANE

PAN-EUROPE

For European banks – The ECB said that banks should adopt a conservative 2017 dividend policy. (Newswires)

 

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

ENDESA (ELE SM) UPGRADED TO BUY FORM HOLD AT BERENBERG

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – EU approved Co’s  multiple sclerosis medicine Ocrevus which has potentially generated USD 1bln in revenue in the first 9 months in the US. (Newswires)

BROKER RECCOMENDATIONS

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER RECOMMENDATIONS

SUBSEA 7 (SUBC NO) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT MACQUARIE

FORTUM (FUM1V FH) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG


US

EQUITIES: SPX +0.7% at 2768, DJI +0.8  at 25574 , NDX +0.7 at 6708

Top sectors: Energy +2.0%, Cons. Disc. +1.6%, Industrials +1.3%

Bottom sectors: Utilities -0.4%, Cons. Stap -0.1%, Telecoms +0.1%

Major US bourses printed fresh record highs on Thursday. Energy stocks were lifted by crude prices surging towards three-year highs, with Brent clearing $70, while WTI climbed to $64. Airlines were also stronger following decent earnings from Delta.

subject: India said to delay proposal to curb prices of generic medecine

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asia equity are mostly positive following on from the record highs in the US. Chinese trade data saw a larger surplus than expected, a beat on exports and a miss on imports
content:
• Asia equity are mostly positive following on from the record highs in the US
  • Chinese trade data saw a larger surplus than expected, a beat on exports and a miss on imports
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, retail sales and earnings from Wells Fargo, JP Morgan and Blackrock

ASIA

Asia equity markets are mostly positive following record highs across all major US indices on optimism heading into earnings season and where energy outperformed with oil at 3yr highs. ASX 200 (Unch) was kept positive throughout the day by commodity-related stocks, but still closed flat due to losses in the largest weighted financials sector. In Japan, index-heavyweight Fast Retailing outperformed and hit its highest in over 2 years after strong quarterly results, although the Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) failed to benefit with the broader market negative on JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and was positive following better than expected Chinese Trade Surplus and Exports, as well as a more convincing liquidity effort by the PBoC. However, the Shanghai Comp (-0.1%) was less decisive as participants also digested disappointing Import numbers and the fact that open market operations still resulted to a net weekly drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid the dampened risk tone in Japan and amid slightly firmer demand in the 40yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 140bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 130bln via 14-day reverse repos. This resulted to a daily net injection of CNY 180bln, but also a weekly net drain of CNY 60bln vs. last week's CNY 510bln net drain. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4932 (Prev. 6.5147)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Dec) 362.0B vs. Exp. 235.2B (Prev. 263.6B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (CNY)(Dec) Y/Y 7.4% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 10.3%)
Chinese Imports (CNY)(Dec) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 11.8% (Prev. 15.6%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 54.69B vs. Exp. 37.00B (Prev. 40.21B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 10.9% vs. Exp. 10.8% (Prev. 12.3%)
Chinese Imports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 4.5% vs. Exp. 15.1% (Prev. 17.7%)

China Customs said China trade outlook is upbeat for this year, but added it will be difficult for Chinese trade to maintain double-digit growth. (Newswires)

Chinese trust companies reportedly placed caps on leveraged funds used for equities. (China Securities Journal)


UK/EU

US President Donald Trump said he would not travel to the UK to open the new American embassy next month, blaming the "bad deal" to relocate it. (Telegraph)


FX

USD remained subdued overnight after yesterday’s weaker than expected PPI data and fallout from the EUR strength post-ECB minutes, which were viewed as hawkish as it suggested forward guidance and policy language could be revisited early this year. As such, most major currencies have stayed close to the prior day’s highs against the greenback with EUR/USD and GBP/USD firmly above the 1.2000 and 1.3500 levels respectively, while USD/JPY languished and briefly approached 111.00 to the downside.

S&P cut Brazil sovereign rating to BB-; Outlook Stable from BB; Outlook Negative. (Newswires)

Turkey purged 262 government employees with an emergency decree. (Twitter/Gazette)
 

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures traded sideways as price action took a breather from yesterday’s ascent and subsequent pullback from fresh 3-year highs and the USD 64/bbl level. Elsewhere, gold was underpinned by a subdued greenback to trade near 4-month highs and with prices on course for a 5th consecutive weekly gain, while copper was relatively flat alongside mixed Chinese trade data which also showed 2017 copper and product imports fell 5.2% Y/Y. 

US Commerce Secretary Ross said results of investigation into national security impact from steel imports have been submitted to President Trump who has 90 days to decide on any potential action. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirmed US plans to reimpose sanctions on Iran, while a separate report states the White House plans to announce decision on Friday. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US sent B2 Bombers to Guam, which will conduct local and regional training sorties amid North Korea threat. (Daily Express)

US President Trump said he "probably" has a very good relationship with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, but didn’t want to comment when asked whether he had spoken with Kim. (Nikkei)

Reports stated that satellite imagery showed tunnelling at North Korea’s nuclear test site. (Yonhap)


US

Treasuries were supported yesterday after China denied reports it considering reducing or halting its purchases of USTs, while prices then hovered around best levels heading in to the release of the latest ECB meeting minutes, which were deemed hawkish.
This allowed some concession heading in to a 30-year auction which stopped screens by 2.1bps, foreign buyers also stepped in and pushed the indirect takedown to the highest level on record, while the BTC was the highest since December 2014. T-Note Futures settle +4 ticks higher at 123-04

Fed's Dudley (voter) said there is a 'strong case' for gradual hikes and that he is worried growth overheating is a risk, while he added the Fed may have to press harder on the breaks at some point. Dudley also said three Fed hikes in 2018 is not an unreasonable starting point and sees inflation rising to target in the medium term and unemployment falling under 4% this year. (Newswires)

subject: Shell (RDSA LN) prepares bid for Netherland's Eneco
Nikkei 225 closes down 0.2% at 23,653
China is expected to increase gasoline and diesel prices by CNY 180/ton and CNY 175/ton respectively on Saturday
China Communist Party Central Committee Plenary to be held January 18th-19th
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mixed despite record highs on Wall St, with Nikkei weighed by a firmer JPY while participants also digest Chinese Trade data
content: Asia equity markets were somewhat mixed as the region failed to take full impetus from the record highs across all major US indices on optimism heading into earnings season and where energy outperformed with oil at 3yr highs. ASX 200 (Unch) was kept positive throughout the day by commodity-related stocks, but still closed flat due to losses in the largest weighted financials sector. In Japan, index-heavyweight Fast Retailing outperformed and hit its highest in over 2 years after strong quarterly results, although the Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) failed to benefit with the broader market negative on JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and was positive following better than expected Chinese Trade Surplus and Exports, as well as a more convincing liquidity effort by the PBoC. However, the Shanghai Comp (-0.1%) was less decisive as participants also digested disappointing Import numbers and the fact that open market operations still resulted to a net weekly drain. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher with support seen amid the dampened risk tone in Japan and amid slightly firmer demand in the 40yr JGB auction.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin confirms US plans to reimpose sanctions on Iran, while a separate report states the White House plans to announce decision on Friday
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher after fresh Wall St. highs, although JPY strength subdues Nikkei 225
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly positive as the region somewhat takes impetus from the positive lead in US where all major indices posted fresh records once again on optimism heading into earnings season and in which energy outperformed with oil at 3yr highs. ASX 200 (+0.2%) is led higher by strength in commodity-related stocks, although gains in the index are restricted by losses in the largest weighted financials sector. In Japan, index-heavyweight Fast Retailing outperforms the Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) after strong quarterly results, although the broader Japanese market is negative on JPY strength. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) is positive after better than expected Chinese trade data and a more convincing liquidity effort by the PBoC, while the Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) is indecisive as operations still resulted to a net weekly drain.

In FX markets, USD remains subdued overnight after yesterday’s weaker than expected PPI data and fallout from the EUR strength post-ECB minutes which were viewed as hawkish, as it stated that forward guidance and language surrounding the policy stance could be revisited early this year. As such, most major currencies have stayed close to the prior day’s highs against the greenback with EUR/USD and GBP/USD firmly above the 1.2000 and 1.3500 levels respectively, while USD/JPY languishes and briefly approached 111.00 to the downside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher with support seen amid the dampened risk tone in Japan, while focus shifts to the upcoming 40yr JGB auction later.
